data.source: World Values Survey (WVS) for polarization measures; World Bank and IMF for government consumption and transfers/subsidies; Polity IV democracy index; Transparency International Corruption Index; Press Freedom Index (Teorell, Holmberg, Rothstein); European Values Study for confidence in parliament
data.wave_or_subset: WVS waves in the 1990s and 2000s; approximately 83 countries; four economic policy questions (1–10 scale)
data.sample_size: Approximately 1,000 respondents per country; about 83 countries
data.unit_of_analysis: Country (cross-national aggregates; sometimes by supporter subgroup: government vs. opposition)
data.notes: Polarization measured primarily as the standard deviation across four WVS questions (equality, private vs. government ownership, personal vs. government responsibility, role of competition). Alternative measures include Esteban-Ray polarization and a bipolarization index; an income-adjusted polarization measure is highly correlated (>0.99) with the unadjusted version. Stability across WVS waves: correlation 0.72–0.81. Government size measured as government consumption (GOVCONS) and transfers and subsidies (GOVTRANSSUB), typically as shares of consumption or GDP. Countries are split by democracy strength using Polity IV. Additional controls include GDP per capita, trade openness, demographics, federal structure, OECD membership, income inequality, social trust, ideological coherence, press freedom, corruption, and confidence in parliament.

method.description: The study constructs country-level measures of political polarization from WVS responses to four economic policy questions and relates them to measures of government size using cross-country regression analyses. It estimates the association separately for weak and strong democracies (Polity IV), examines robustness to multiple control sets, employs alternative polarization metrics, and explores mechanisms via legislative/government fragmentation and supporter subgroup polarization.
steps: Collect WVS responses to four 1–10 economic policy questions for each country and wave (1990s–2000s).
Compute polarization measures (primary: standard deviation; alternatives: Esteban-Ray polarization, bipolarization; income-adjusted versions).
Aggregate polarization at the country level and, where relevant, by government vs. opposition supporters.
Assemble government size outcomes: government consumption (GOVCONS) and transfers/subsidies (GOVTRANSSUB) from World Bank/IMF.

Merge covariates: GDP per capita, trade openness, demographics, federal structure, OECD status, inequality, social trust, press freedom, corruption, confidence in parliament, geographic/colonial controls.
Classify countries by democracy strength using the Polity IV democracy index (weak vs. strong).
Estimate cross-country OLS regressions under basic, short, and long specifications; report coefficients and fit.
Conduct robustness checks using alternative polarization measures, income-adjusted polarization, and additional controls (ideological coherence, response rate).
Test interactions with political fragmentation (HERFGOV, HERFLEG) and analyze supporter subgroup polarization (government vs. opposition).
Interpret results across democracy groups and specifications; assess potential endogeneity and alternative mechanisms.
method.models: Cross-country OLS regressions with alternative control specifications (basic, short, long); subgroup analyses by democracy strength; interaction terms with government/legislative fragmentation indices (HERFGOV, HERFLEG).
method.outcome_variable: Government size: government consumption (GOVCONS, reported as share of total consumption or GDP) and transfers and subsidies (GOVTRANSSUB, share of GDP).
method.independent_variables: Polarization measures from WVS (standard deviation across four economic policy questions; Esteban-Ray polarization; bipolarization); polarization among government supporters and opposition; income-adjusted polarization.
method.control_variables: GDP per capita; trade openness; demographic structure (age shares); federal structure; OECD membership; geographic and colonial origin controls; income inequality (Gini); social trust; ideological coherence; press freedom; corruption; confidence in parliament; turnout; party system measures (HERFGOV, HERFLEG, number of parties).

results.summary: Across countries, higher political polarization is associated with smaller government size, especially in strong democracies. The negative relationship is robust across control specifications and alternative polarization measures. Effects are negligible and statistically insignificant in weak democracies. In strong democracies, polarization is also linked to lower transfers and subsidies. Polarization among government supporters is more predictive of spending than polarization among opposition supporters. Legislative/government fragmentation tends to amplify the relationship, though most interaction terms are not individually significant. A one standard deviation increase in polarization predicts about a 4 percentage point decrease in government consumption.
